verses.text: In that same year, at the beginning of the reign of King Zedekiah of Judah, in the fifth month of the fourth year, the prophet Hananiah, son of Azzur, from Gibeon, spoke to me in the house of the LORD in the presence of the priests and all the people. He said:
verses.comment: This introduction situates the prophecy during King Zedekiah's reign. Public prophetic challenges like this occurred in the temple, highlighting the seriousness of Hananiah's declaration.

verses.text: ‘This is what the LORD of Armies, the God of Israel, says: I have broken the yoke of the king of Babylon.’
verses.comment: Hananiah falsely promises Israel's liberation from Babylonian domination, directly contradicting Jeremiah's earlier warnings. This demonstrates that not every prophetic voice is authentically sent from God (Jer. 23:21).

verses.text: ‘Within two years, I will bring back to this place all the vessels of the LORD’s house that Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon took from here and carried to Babylon.’
verses.comment: The restoration of the temple vessels symbolizes the restoration of proper worship and relationship with God. Notice how the physical presence of holy objects is connected to God’s blessing upon His people.

verses.text: ‘And I will also bring back to this place Jeconiah son of Jehoiakim, king of Judah, and all the exiles of Judah who went to Babylon,’ declares the LORD, ‘for I will break the yoke of the king of Babylon.’
verses.comment: Hananiah doubles down, claiming even the exiled king and captives will return. This contradicts Jeremiah's true prophecy. The emphasis on the king’s return relates to God's covenantal faithfulness, but prophetic falsehood leads Israel astray.

verses.text: Then the prophet Jeremiah spoke to the prophet Hananiah in the presence of the priests and all the people standing in the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: The confrontation occurs before everyone, highlighting the communal discernment of true prophecy—a principle later echoed in the New Testament for discerning spirits (1 Thess. 5:21-22).

verses.text: And Jeremiah the prophet said, ‘Amen! May the LORD do so; may the LORD fulfill the words you have prophesied by bringing back the vessels of the LORD’s house and all the exiles from Babylon to this place.’
verses.comment: Jeremiah's response is both ironic and pastoral—he hopes for good news but warns he only speaks what God truly reveals. This mirrors later New Testament admonitions to test prophecies (1 John 4:1).

verses.text: ‘Nevertheless, hear now this word that I speak in your hearing and in the hearing of all the people.’
verses.comment: Jeremiah emphatically calls everyone to attention, underscoring the responsibility of the whole community to listen and discern God’s authentic message.

verses.text: ‘The prophets who were before me and before you from ancient times prophesied war, disaster, and plague against many countries and great kingdoms.’
verses.comment: Jeremiah appeals to prophetic tradition: true prophets often speak challenging words, preparing the community for repentance and purification. This reflects the biblical pattern of suffering preceding restoration.

verses.text: ‘As for the prophet who prophesies peace, when the word of that prophet comes to pass, then it will be known that the LORD has truly sent the prophet.’
verses.comment: Jeremiah references the test of a true prophet, as in Deuteronomy—the fulfillment of prophecy is the sign of its divine origin (Deut. 18:22).

verses.text: Then the prophet Hananiah took the yoke from the neck of Jeremiah the prophet and broke it.
verses.comment: Hananiah’s dramatic act is intended to symbolize the breaking of Babylon’s oppression. In biblical tradition, physical signs often accompany God’s word, but when misused, they become presumption rather than faith.

verses.text: And Hananiah spoke in the presence of all the people, saying, ‘This is what the LORD says: In the same way, I will break the yoke of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon from the neck of all nations within two years.’ But Jeremiah the prophet went his way.
verses.comment: Hananiah falsely assures a quick deliverance, while Jeremiah, trusting in the Lord, refrains from responding further—sometimes silence witnesses to truth more powerfully than words.

verses.text: After this, the word of the LORD came to Jeremiah, after Hananiah the prophet had broken the yoke from his neck:
verses.comment: God’s direct revelation supersedes human presumption. Notice the pattern: even prophetic action is subordinate to God’s Word, a theme that echoes in the authority given to Peter and the apostles (Matt. 16:18–19).

verses.text: ‘Go and tell Hananiah: This is what the LORD says: You have broken wooden yokes, but you have made in their place yokes of iron.’
verses.comment: Iron yokes signify a heavier judgment as a result of false prophecy. Rebelling against God’s correction only increases hardship—recalling how sin hardens the heart against grace.

verses.text: For this is what the LORD of Armies, the God of Israel, says: I have put a yoke of iron on the neck of all these nations, that they may serve Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, and they shall serve him; even the wild animals I have given to him.’
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty extends over all nations and creation. His judgments are just, even using foreign rulers as instruments. This foreshadows New Testament teaching that all authority is established by God (Rom. 13:1).

verses.text: Then Jeremiah the prophet said to Hananiah the prophet, ‘Listen, Hananiah! The LORD has not sent you, but you have made this people trust in a lie.’
verses.comment: Leading God’s people astray by false prophecy is a grave offense. Authentic leadership and true doctrine are necessary to safeguard the faith of believers.

verses.text: Therefore, this is what the LORD says: ‘I am about to remove you from the face of the earth. This year you will die, because you have spoken rebellion against the LORD.’
verses.comment: Judgment falls swiftly on those who lead others into error. Note the seriousness with which God protects the purity and unity of His people—a principle Christ affirms regarding the consequences of causing a believer to stumble (Matt. 18:6).

verses.text: So Hananiah the prophet died that same year, in the seventh month.
verses.comment: The prophecy is fulfilled, confirming Jeremiah’s authority as God’s true spokesman. The narrative affirms God’s faithfulness to His word and the danger of opposing His appointed leaders—echoing the apostolic warnings about false teachers.
